text.content: AI is a branch of computer science that enables machines (software program) to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence. These tasks include problem-solving, decision-making, language understanding, and image recognition. AI systems are designed to learn from data, adapt to new inputs, and improve their performance over time.

ML is a subset of AI that focuses on teaching computers to learn patterns from data without being explicitly programmed. Instead of following predefined rules, ML models analyze large datasets and make predictions or decisions based on patterns they find.

This course introduces the fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), covering how machines learn, think, and make decisions using data. You'll explore types of AI, including Narrow and General AI, and learn machine learning techniques like supervised and unsupervised learning. Key topics include deep learning, neural networks, natural language processing (NLP), and computer vision, helping AI analyze text, images, and videos. You'll also discover real-world applications in healthcare, finance, and automation, work on hands-on projects using Python and ML libraries like TensorFlow, and discuss the ethics and future of AI in society. This course is perfect for beginners looking to understand AI and gain practical skills.
*NOTE: To get an upper hand in this course you must foucus on these subjects.

items: Mathematics: Concepts like linear algebra, probability, statistics, and calculus are crucial for understanding ML algorithms.
Programming: Proficiency in languages like Python (preferred for ML), R, or Java is important for coding AI models.
Data structures & algorithms: Helps in optimizing AI solutions and understanding computational efficiency.
Databases & SQL: Knowledge of how data is stored, retrieved, and managed is useful for AI applications.
Machine learning basics: Understanding supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning concepts.
Neural network & deep learning: Essential for advanced AI models like image and speech recognition.
Computer science fundamentals: Includes basic operating system concepts, networking, and problem-solving skills.

text.content: This syllabus is designed for a 4-year (8-semester) BTech in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, reflecting an average curriculum from global and Indian universities. It covers foundational computer science, mathematics, core AI/ML concepts, advanced topics, and practical applications, with hands-on projects and ethical considerations.

content.heading: Semester 1: Foundations of Computing and Mathematics
content.objective: Objective: Build a strong foundation in programming and mathematical concepts essential for AI/ML.
items: Mathematics 1st: Calculus (limits, derivatives, integrals), linear algebra (matrices, vectors, eigenvalues), probability basics.
Programming Fundamentals: Introduction to programming with Python, data types, loops, functions, and basic algorithms.
Computer Science Basics: Introduction to computer organization, operating systems, and logic design.
Physics for Computing: Mechanics, electromagnetism, and their relevance to computing hardware.
Communication Skills: Technical writing, presentations, and collaborative skills for project work.
Lab: Python programming lab (basic scripts, data handling).

content.heading: Semester 2: Data Structures and Advanced Mathematics
content.objective: Objective: Develop skills in data organization, storage, and advanced mathematical tools.
items: Mathematics 2nd: Multivariate calculus, differential equations, statistics (mean, variance, distributions).
Data Structures: Arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, graphs, and their implementation in Python.
Introduction to Databases: Relational databases, SQL, data modeling, and basic queries.
Digital Systems: Boolean algebra, logic gates, and circuit design.
Environmental Science: Sustainability and technology's role in environmental solutions.
Lab: Data structures lab (implementing algorithms in Python) and SQL lab.

content.heading: Semester 3: Algorithms and AI Foundations
content.objective: Objective: Introduce core AI concepts and algorithmic thinking for problem-solving.
items: Design and Analysis of Algorithms: Sorting, searching, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, and complexity analysis.
Discrete Mathematics: Set theory, graph theory, combinatorics, and logic for AI reasoning.
Introduction to Artificial Intelligence: History of AI, search algorithms (BFS, DFS, A*), knowledge representation.
Object-Oriented Programming: Concepts using Python/Java, classes, inheritance, and polymorphism.
Lab: AI basics lab (implementing search algorithms) and OOP lab.
Mini Project: Simple AI application (e.g., tic-tac-toe with minimax algorithm).

content.heading: Semester 4: Machine Learning Basics and Systems
content.objective: Objective: Lay the groundwork for ML algorithms and system-level understanding.
items: Probability and Statistics for ML: Random variables, hypothesis testing, Bayesian inference, and distributions.
Machine Learning Fundamentals: Supervised learning (linear regression, logistic regression), unsupervised learning (k-means clustering), evaluation metrics.
Operating Systems: Process management, memory management, and file systems.
Computer Networks: Basics of networking, TCP/IP, and data transmission protocols.
Elective 1st: Choose from topics like data visualization or IoT fundamentals.
Lab: ML lab (using scikit-learn for regression and clustering) and OS/networks lab.

content.heading: Semester 5: Advanced ML and Neural Networks
content.objective: Objective: Deepen ML knowledge and introduce neural networks for complex tasks.
items: Advanced Machine Learning: Decision trees, SVM, ensemble methods (random forests, boosting), feature engineering.
Introduction to Neural Networks: Perceptrons, backpropagation, activation functions, and gradient descent.
Database Systems: Advanced SQL, NoSQL databases, and data warehousing.
Software Engineering: SDLC, agile methodologies, and version control (Git).
Lab: Neural networks lab (using TensorFlow/PyTorch for basic models) and database lab.
Mini Project: ML-based project (e.g., predicting house prices using regression).

content.heading: Semester 6: Deep Learning and Applications
content.objective: Objective: Explore advanced AI applications in text, images, and sequential data.
items: Deep Learning: Convolutional neural networks (CNNs), recurrent neural networks (RNNs), transfer learning.
Natural Language Processing (NLP): Text preprocessing, sentiment analysis, word embeddings (Word2Vec, BERT).
Computer Vision: Image processing, object detection, and facial recognition.
Elective 2nd: Choose from robotics, reinforcement learning, or big data analytics.
Lab: Deep learning lab (building CNNs/RNNs) and NLP/CV lab.
Mini Project: NLP or CV project (e.g., chatbot or image classifier).

content.heading: Semester 7: Specialized Topics and Ethics
content.objective: Objective: Address specialized AI topics, ethical issues, and begin a significant project.
items: Reinforcement Learning: Markov decision processes, Q-learning, policy gradients.
AI Ethics and Societal Impact: Bias in AI, privacy, fairness, and regulatory considerations.
Cloud Computing for AI: Deploying AI models on AWS/Azure, scalability, and APIs.
Elective 3rd: Quantum AI, cognitive computing, or human-computer interaction.
Lab: RL lab (implementing Q-learning) and cloud deployment lab.
Capstone Project (Part 1st): Proposal and initial development of a real-world AI/ML application.

content.heading: Semester 8: Capstone and Emerging Trends
content.objective: Objective: Culminate learning with a major project, explore cutting-edge AI, and prepare for industry/research.
items: Emerging Trends in AI: Generative AI (GANs, diffusion models), AI in healthcare, and autonomous systems.
Big Data Technologies: Hadoop, Spark, and handling large-scale datasets for AI.
Elective IV: Advanced computer vision, audio processing, or AI for cybersecurity.
Capstone Project (Part 2nd): Complete and present a comprehensive AI/ML project (e.g., medical diagnosis system or autonomous navigation).
Internship/Seminar: Industry internship or research seminar on AI trends.

text.content: *NOTE: This syllabus ensures graduates are well-equipped for roles like AI engineer, data scientist, or ML researcher, with a balance of theory, practice, and ethical awareness.

items: Practical Focus: Each semester includes labs and projects to ensure hands-on experience with tools like Python, TensorFlow, PyTorch, and scikit-learn.
Electives: Allow specialization in areas like robotics, quantum AI, or NLP, reflecting diverse university offerings.
Ethics and Applications: Emphasis on real-world applications (healthcare, finance, automation) and ethical considerations aligns with global trends.
Alignment with Universities: Based on curricula from IIT Hyderabad, BITS Pilani, Sharda University, Reva University, and global standards (e.g., MIT, Stanford).
Assessment: Combination of exams, assignments, lab work, and project evaluations, with capstone projects carrying significant weight in the final year.
